alcohol related liver disease: There's currently no specific medical treatment for ARLD. The main treatment is to stop drinking, preferably for the rest of your life. This reduces the risk of further damage to your liver and gives it the best chance of recovering. A liver transplant may be required in severe cases where the liver has stopped functioning and doesn't improve when you stop drinking alcohol.
appendicitis: In most cases of appendicitis, the appendix needs to be surgically removed as soon as possible.

flu: Rest, stay hydrated, and manage symptoms with over-the-counter medications like paracetamol or ibuprofen. Antiviral medication may be prescribed. Avoid spreading the flu by covering your mouth and nose when sneezing or coughing, and maintaining good hand hygiene.
heart_failure: Immediate medical attention is needed. Treatment may involve medications to manage symptoms, lifestyle changes such as dietary adjustments and exercise, and in some cases, medical procedures or surgery.
kidney_stones: Treatment depends on the size and location of the kidney stone. Small stones may pass on their own with plenty of fluids. Larger stones may require medical intervention, such as shock wave lithotripsy, ureteroscopy, or surgical removal.
kidney_infection: Kidney infections are typically treated with antibiotics to eliminate the bacterial infection. Pain relievers may also be recommended to manage discomfort.
lyme_disease: Lyme disease is typically treated with antibiotics. Early diagnosis and treatment are important to prevent more severe complications.
malaria: Malaria is treated with antimalarial medications. The choice of medication depends on the type of malaria and the severity of the symptoms.

obesity: Treatment for obesity involves a combination of diet, exercise, lifestyle changes, and in some cases, medication or surgical interventions
oral_thrush_in_adults: Oral thrush in adults is typically treated with antifungal medicines to eliminate the fungal infection.
tooth decay: Tooth decay can be prevented through good oral hygiene practices such as regular brushing, flossing, and avoiding sugary foods and drinks. If decay has already occurred, treatment may involve dental fillings, crowns, or other procedures depending on the severity of the damage.
tonsillitis: Over-the-counter painkillers such as paracetamol and ibuprofen can help relieve painful symptoms. If symptoms persist or worsen, consult a healthcare professional.
tuberculosis (TB): Treatment for tuberculosis (TB) usually involves a long course of antibiotics lasting several months. Early diagnosis and proper medical care are crucial for effective treatment.
tinnitus: Treatment for tinnitus depends on the underlying cause. It can include sound therapy, counseling, cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT), and tinnitus retraining therapy (TRT). In some cases, addressing related conditions such as hearing loss or earwax buildup may alleviate tinnitus symptoms.
ulcerative_colitis: Treatment for ulcerative colitis may involve medication such as aminosalicylates (ASAs), corticosteroids, and immunosuppressants to reduce inflammation and manage symptoms.
In severe cases, surgery to remove the colon and rectum (proctocolectomy) may be considered.
Dietary changes and lifestyle modifications can also play a role in managing symptoms and promoting remission.
underactive_thyroid: Underactive thyroid, also known as hypothyroidism, is typically treated with hormone replacement therapy using medications like levothyroxine.
Regular monitoring of thyroid hormone levels is important to ensure effective treatment.
Lifestyle changes such as maintaining a healthy diet, staying physically active, and managing stress can also contribute to managing the condition.
urticaria: Antihistamines can help relieve discomfort and itching associated with urticaria.
Identifying and avoiding triggers that cause urticaria outbreaks is important.
In severe cases, a doctor may recommend other medications or treatments to manage symptoms.
urinary_tract_infection: Over-the-counter painkillers such as paracetamol can help with pain.
Drinking plenty of fluids may also help alleviate symptoms.
Antibiotics are commonly prescribed to treat urinary tract infections.
If symptoms persist or worsen, it's important to consult a healthcare professional.
varicose_eczema: Long-term treatment with a combination of:
- Emollients (moisturizers) to keep the skin hydrated.
- Topical corticosteroids to reduce inflammation and itching.
- Compression stockings to improve blood circulation in the affected area.
Consult a healthcare professional for proper diagnosis and treatment.
varicose_veins: Taking regular exercise to improve blood circulation.
Avoiding standing up for long periods to reduce pressure on the veins.
Elevating the affected area when resting to reduce swelling.
Wearing compression stockings to improve blood flow and reduce symptoms.
Consult a healthcare professional for proper diagnosis and treatment.
venous_leg_ulcer: Treatment should always be carried out by a healthcare professional trained in compression therapy for leg ulcers.
Wearing compression stockings to improve blood flow and reduce swelling.
Cleaning and dressing the ulcer regularly to promote healing.
Elevating the affected leg when resting to reduce swelling.
Consult a healthcare professional for proper diagnosis and treatment.
whooping_cough: Clean away mucus and sick from your or your child's mouth.
Take painkillers such as paracetamol or ibuprofen for a fever.
Consult a healthcare professional for proper diagnosis and treatment.
yellow_fever: There is no specific treatment for yellow fever.
Supportive care includes rest, hydration, and pain relievers.
Vaccination is available to prevent yellow fever.
Consult a healthcare professional for more information and guidance.
